question: What should I bring to the hospital?
assumption: There is a specific length of time that I will be in the hospital.
evidence: length of stay postpartum differs significantly across birthing hospitals, and depends on length of labor, whether the birth was vaginal or cesarean, maternal–fetal complications, regional and hospital routines, and type of reimbursement the hospital receives. In the US, women stay an average of 48 hours for a vaginal birth. Federal law requires that most insurance companies cover a postdelivery hospital stay of 48 hours for vaginal birth and 96 hours for cesarean birth

assumption: There are specific activities that I will be doing while in the hospital.
evidence: varying is the practice of rooming-in, whereby the newborn remains with the mother in her postpartum room, which may or may not be standard practice and is based on the mother's and newborn's condition and hospital routines. Likewise, support for breastfeeding, including access to lactation professionals, varies across hospitals.

assumption: There may be a need to leave the room and go to other areas of the hospital.
evidence: Parents can visit and spend time with their babies who stay in the NICU.

assumption: The hospital may not provide items like soap or shampoo.
evidence: After delivery, you'll be looking forward to a shower. Bring shampoo, conditioner, face wash, soap, a toothbrush, toothbrush, your hairbrush, and any other items that will make you feel a little bit more like yourself.

question: At what age should my child have a phone?
assumption: There may be an age that is considered too young for a child to have a phone.
evidence: Pediatrics associations recommend avoiding the use of mobile devices (MDs) in children aged 0-2 years and limiting them to one hour per day for children aged 3-5 years.

assumption: The age at which a child should have a phone may depend on their gender.
evidence: The findings showed that adolescent females as compared with adolescent males exhibited significantly higher degrees of smartphone dependence and smartphone influence. Positive correlations were observed between the duration of smartphone use on weekends and the vitality/mental health of the male adolescents; negative correlations were found between smartphone dependence and the vitality/mental health of males.

assumption: There are potential dangers associated with a child having a phone.
evidence: With regards to our objectives, firstly, we found evidence to suggest that greater use of MP/WD may be associated with poorer mental health in children and adolescents, but that the strength of the associations vary partly depending on the time and nature of MP/WD usage.

assumption: There may be potential benefits to a child having a phone.
evidence: cell phones can be leveraged to enhance student collaboration, engagement, and idea-sharing across grade levels and subject areas. Regarding the potential benefits of using cell phones as part of teaching and learning, Marcoux (2009) suggested that they can help to enhance student research, to connect students with school activities and events, and to facilitate teaching digital responsibility

assumption: There is a right age for a child to have a phone.
evidence: Our findings suggest that whether and when children acquire their own mobile phones seems to have few measurable implications for adjustme

assumption: Children are better off having a phone.
evidence: Studies reveal that cell phone use in classrooms have an array of other beneficial effects for young people, including improving motivation, being relevant for future work, supporting pedagogical innovation and greater interactivity in the classroom  cell phone use has high potential for students involved in distance learning. Further, in a study of 92 preservice teacher candidates, Thomas and O'Bannon  reported that 61% of respondents reported that cell phones provided anytime or anywhere purposeful learning opportunities.

assumption: There are pros and cons to children having a phone.
evidence: Experimental research reviewed herein suggests that the interactivity allowed by mobile devices has benefits over passive viewing (for example, of television) for young children's learning and self-regulation, but studies of naturalistic use suggest increased use of mobile devices is associated with poorer language and self-regulation

question: Why is my hair falling?
assumption: Hair falling out may not be normal.
evidence: Many new moms experience excessive hair shedding after pregnancy. Hair shedding usually peaks about four months after giving birth. By their child's first birthday, most women regain their normal hair growth. If your hair does not regain its normal fullness after one year, you may want to see a dermatologist. Something else may be causing your hair to fall out. People lose hair for many reasons, and an accurate diagnosis is essential for effective treatment.

assumption: If hair is falling out, something might be wrong.
evidence: Talk with your provider if you continue to lose hair for more than six months. You might have another condition that causes hair loss, such as iron deficiency or thyroid disease.

assumption: There might be a need to change how hair is handled to prevent it from falling out.
evidence: There's no treatment for postpartum hair loss, but these steps can help your hair feel fuller and prevent further hair loss and damage: choose a shampoo and conditioner that add volume, treat your hair with care, try a different hairstyle.

assumption: There is a certain amount of hair loss that is considered normal.
evidence: Many new moms see noticeable hair loss a few months after having a baby. This is normal — and it is not true hair loss. Dermatologists refer to this condition as excessive hair shedding. The excessive shedding is caused by falling estrogen levels

assumption: There may be times in life when increased hair loss is normal.
evidence: Many new moms experience excessive hair shedding after pregnancy. Hair shedding usually peaks about four months after giving birth.

assumption: There are common causes of increased hair loss.
evidence: Postpartum hair loss is commonplace, During the first weeks of postpartum, hairs enter telogen in a synchronous wave to reach about 30% in average after nine weeks. This explains the clinical observation that postpartum hair loss is experienced two to four months after childbirth. It usually continues for 6 to 24 weeks but rarely persists up to 15 months.

assumption: Increased hair loss might improve on its own.
evidence: Postpartum hair loss from the scalp is diffuse but is accentuated along the anterior hair line. Virtually the whole hair is replaced after several weeks unless some other process unmasks female pattern alopecia.

assumption: There are treatments available for increased hair loss.
evidence: There is no treatment for Postpartum Hair Loss. Mild-to-moderate Female Pattern Hair Loss (FPHL) in women can be treated with oral antiandrogen therapies (cyproterone acetate and spironolactone) and/or topical minoxidil with good results in many cases. If used correctly, available medical treatments arrest the progression of the disease and reverse miniaturization in most patients with mild-to-moderate FPHL. Hair systems and surgery may be considered for selected cases of severe FPHL.

question: Is it common for a baby's hair to fallout?
assumption: A baby's hair falling out may be a normal part of the hair follicle cycle.
evidence: Almost all newborns lose some or all of their hair. This is normal and to be expected. The baby hair falls out before the mature hair comes in. So hair loss occurring in the first six months of life is not a cause for concern.

assumption: The age of the baby may affect the amount of hair loss.
evidence: Many babies also lose hair on the back of the scalp at age four months as their hair grows at varying times and rates. In very rare cases, babies may be born with alopecia (hair loss), which can occur by itself or in association with certain abnormalities of the nails and the teeth. Later in childhood, hair loss may be due to medications, a scalp injury, or a medical or nutritional problem.

assumption: There may be tests available to determine the reason for a baby's hair loss.
evidence: Tinea capitis is a common dermatophyte infection that primarily affects children, including infants. Differential diagnosis of tinea capitis includes AA and ACC. The presence of black dot hairs (broken hairs within the lesion), significant erythema and scaling, and posterior cervical lymphadenopathy all favor tinea capitis. Both a swab culture of the affected skin and a hair from the affected area should be submitted for fungal culture.

assumption: There may be treatments available for hair loss in a baby.
evidence: Tinea capitis is a common dermatophyte infection that primarily affects children, including infants. Patients can be successfully treated with oral antifungal medications (e.g., terbinafine and griseofulvin) plus antifungal shampoos such as ketoconazole 2% shampoo to prevent shedding. Many children under 1 year can be adequately treated with topical azoles alone.

assumption: Loss of hair in a baby may not always be a sign of a medical problem.
evidence: Very commonly, a baby loses her hair where she rubs her scalp against the mattress or as a result of a head banging habit. As she starts to move more and sit up or outgrow this head rubbing or banging behavior, this type of hair loss will correct itself.

assumption: Not all babies are expected to have a lot of hair.
evidence: Newborns are born with varying amounts of hair.

question: How many hours should a baby sleep?
assumption: Babies need a lot of sleep.
evidence: The average newborn sleeps much of the day and night, waking only for feedings every few hours. It is often hard for new parents to know how long and how often a newborn should sleep.

assumption: There is an ideal amount of sleep that does not vary from baby to baby.
evidence: Infants* 4 months to 12 months should sleep 12 to 16 hours per 24 hours (including naps) on a regular basis to promote optimal health.

assumption: The amount of sleep a baby needs differs from an adult.
evidence: sleep duration recommendations: newborns 14-17 hours, infants (4-11mos) 12-15 hours, adults 7-9 hours

assumption: There is a normal average sleep time for babies.
evidence: Infants* 4 months to 12 months should sleep 12 to 16 hours per 24 hours (including naps) on a regular basis to promote optimal health.

assumption: Too little sleep could lead to negative side effects.
evidence: Not getting enough sleep at night is generally associated with daytime sleepiness, daytime fatigue, depressed mood, poor daytime functioning, and other health and safety problems

assumption: There can be consequences if a baby does not get enough sleep.
evidence: Regularly sleeping fewer than the number of recommended hours is associated with attention, behavior, and learning problems. Insufficient sleep also increases the risk of accidents, injuries, hypertension, obesity, diabetes, and depression.

question: My baby has a diaper rash, what cream should I use?
assumption: Diaper rash requires treatment.
evidence: Diaper rash usually goes away within 2 to 3 days with home care, although it can last longer.

assumption: There is a specific topical treatment for diaper rash.
evidence: Creams and ointments containing zinc oxide or petroleum help to soothe skin and protect it from moisture. They should be smeared on thickly (like cake icing) at each diaper change.

assumption: Diaper rash is caused by something.
evidence: Usually, diaper rash is the result of an irritation, infection, or allergy.

assumption: There are different kinds of treatments for diaper rash.
evidence: Generally, a diaper rash can be treated successfully at home with these practices: keep the diaper area clean and dry, rince the area with warm water, apply cream or oinment, increase airflow, breastmilk. Doctor prescriptions may include hydrocortozone cream, antifungal cream, antibiotics.

assumption: Each type of treatment may have side effects.
evidence: tell your doctor if you have ever had any unusual or allergic reaction to this medicine or any other medicines.

assumption: There may be consequences if diaper rash is left untreated.
evidence: Yeast infection — Yeast (Candida) infections can develop if irritant dermatitis is not treated for more than a few days. Signs of yeast diaper dermatitis include dark red areas of skin with or without raised yellow, fluid-filled pustules that can rupture and flake (

question: When is it time to push?
assumption: Pushing is necessary for the baby to come out.
evidence: it is the environment and the undisturbed nature of the birth that are crucial factors in the occurrence of the fetus ejection reflex. He depicts a situation in which there is no conscious, active pushing: the baby is effectively expelled from the mother's body. This is reflected in our narratives. Leah described how: “…baby came so quick, just after a few big breaths, and I didn't even feel like I needed to push, it was just so-, just like baby glided out.”

assumption: There may be different philosophies regarding whether to push or not.
evidence: The “old way” of assisting women during second-stage labor typically involves pushing immediately at 10 cm regardless of whether the woman has an urge to push;. the best approach based on current evidence is to encourage the woman to do whatever comes naturally; for example, bearing down and holding it as long as she can, rather than insisting that she hold her breath for 10 to 15 seconds to the count of 10

assumption: There may be potential harm to the baby or mother if pushing is done too early or too late.
evidence: If you want to push but you're not fully dilated, your health care provider will ask you to hold back. Pushing too soon could make you tired and cause your cervix to swell, which might delay delivery. Pant or blow your way through the contractions.

assumption: There may be someone present during labor to guide and advise on when to push.
evidence: Your health care provider will ask you to bear down during each contraction or tell you when to push. Or you might be asked to push when you feel the urge to do so.

question: Do you have tips on using a breast pump?
assumption: Using a breast pump may be hard and even scary.
evidence: Experiences using a breast pump vary woman to woman and a key takeaway may be: A detailed clinical assessment of maternal experiences related to pumping could potentially improve the pumping experience and might lead to improve breastfeeding duration.

assumption: There are benefits to breastfeeding.
evidence: Breastfeeding prevents infectious and allergic disease throughout infancy, and breastfeeding for at least 12 months is recommended by the World Health Organization, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the American Academy of Pediatrics

assumption: There are different kinds of breast pumps.
evidence: There are three major types of breast pumps: Manual, battery powered pumps, and electric.

assumption: It may be necessary to pump every day.
evidence: For parents who choose to exclusively pump, or pump in order to increase milk supply, it is important to empty the breasts effectively and efficiently. Parents are commonly told to pump at the same frequency as their infant would feed at the breast. In the newborn stage, a parents exclusively pumping would expect to pump 8-12 times daily.

assumption: There are circumstances in which using a breast pump is beneficial.
evidence: With the improved electric pumps, women are able to express as much milk as their infants would remove in a comparable period of at-the-breast feeding. Thus, it is possible that this quiet revolution in milk expression could benefit mothers. To the extent that the longer period of feeding infants human milk documented in the IFPS II5 and suggested by the results of other studies represents a net increase in milk production

assumption: There are tips and tricks that can make using a breast pump easier.
evidence: Lactation consultants can: Help you with your breast pump. This isn't always possible, especially if you see a lactation consultant in the hospital. A lactation consultant will look at your flange, the plastic piece that fits over your nipple. An improper fit can impact how much milk you pump.

assumption: Using a breast pump may get easier over time.
evidence: There are many reasons you might want to pump, hand express breast milk, or feed your baby pumped breast milk. Having expressed breast milk can allow your baby to drink your breast milk from a bottle. While it takes practice, skill, and coordination, it gets easier over time.

question: Is it okay to wake up on right side?
assumption: There is a benefit to sleeping on the left side during pregnancy.
evidence: Sleeping on the left side during pregnancy facilitates blood flow, ensuring that vital organs and the baby receive the nutrients and oxygen  This position also decreases the likelihood of swelling in the ankles and legs. Sleeping on the right side can put pressure on the liver, so it is not optimal. But experts generally agree that it is safe to sleep on the right side for short intervals.

assumption: There may be some evidence to support or dispute these benefits.
evidence: it was important to highlight that the evidence does not support the view that there is an increased likelihood of stillbirth associated with going to sleep on one's right side irrespective of the time of reporting compared to going to sleep on one's left side.

assumption: There are some methods to maintain a left-sided sleeping position.
evidence: You can place a pillow between your legs, against your lower back, or beneath your abdomen. You can also try a full-body pillow, many of which are designed specifically to support pregnant sleepers.

assumption: Gestational age may have an impact on sleep position.
evidence: Overall, the evidence suggests that there may be an increased risk of stillbirth after 28+0 weeks and babies being born small for gestational age (SGA) associated with going to sleep on one's back (in other words in the supine position) compared to going to sleep on one's left-hand side

assumption: It may be difficult to always sleep on the left side.
evidence: Some pregnant people experience discomfort and dizziness while on their backs, so may be less inclined to sleep in that position. But many naturally gravitate to sleeping on their backs and may unintentionally end up in this position. In the second and third trimesters of pregnancy, people who wake up on their backs should simply return to their sides.

assumption: There may be potential negative consequences if I accidentally roll over to the right side during sleep.
evidence: Sleeping on the right side can put pressure on the liver

question: What are ways to destress a toddler?
assumption: Toddlers can experience stress.
evidence: Researchers recognize that children as early as infancy experience stress and may suffer long-lasting consequences of stress

assumption: There are signs that can indicate if a toddler is stressed.
evidence: Emotional lability/temper tantrums; gastrointestinal symptoms; repetitive behaviors; increased fears; sleep disturbance; increased aggression

assumption: There are common causes of stress in toddlers.
evidence: Relocations, divorce, new parental figures, new child in the house, loss of a family member, loss of a pet, etc. Anything within the family structure can cause stress to the child ages 0-3, especially if it causes stress to others in the home.

assumption: Prolonged stress in a toddler may have harmful effects.
evidence_source: Toxic Stress: How the Body's Response Can Harm a ...Nationwide Children's Hospitalhttps://www.nationwidechildrens.org › 2017/07 › toxi...
evidence: Toxic stress results from adverse experiences that may be sustained for a long period of time. This type of stress can disrupt early brain development, compromise the functioning of important biological systems, and lead to long-term health problems

assumption: There are natural options to destress a toddler.
evidence: In addition to boosting a child's health and development, play helps to build the safe, stable and nurturing relationships that buffer against toxic stress and build social-emotional resilience. The mutual joy and one-on-one interaction that happens during play can manage the body's stress response.

assumption: There are signs of stress in a toddler that may require contacting a pediatrician.
evidence: Tantrums that involve aggression, harming oneself on purpose, not being able to calm down or that last longer than 25 minutes may be a sign of an underlying psychiatric disorder and should be assessed by a qualified mental health professional

question: How can I help my baby when she gets heat rash?
assumption: Babies can develop heat rash.
evidence: ​Heat rash is seen most often in babies and young children.

assumption: Heat rash may not resolve on its own and may require treatment.
evidence: Once you start cooling your body down, a mild heat rash could go away within a day. On average, heat rashes last two to three days. More severe heat rashes can last up to a couple of weeks without treatment.

assumption: There are treatments available for heat rash.
evidence: Depending on the severity of your heat rash, you can treat your rash at home by: keeping skin cool and dry, wearing cotton clothing, eliminating friction, using anti-itch cream, and using anti-fever medicines.

assumption: Heat rash can be differentiated from other types of rashes.
evidence: It is caused when the sweat gland openings become blocked. This results in little red bumps around the sweat duct openings.

assumption: There are preventive measures that can be taken to avoid heat rash.
evidence: You can prevent heat rashes by: wearing lightweight clothing,  staying in environments with air flow or air conditioning, keeping the body cool and dry, and staying hydrated.

question: When does babies start to crawl?
assumption: All babies eventually start crawling.
evidence: A few children never crawl. Instead, they use alternative methods, such as scooting on their bottoms or slithering on their stomachs. As long as your baby is coordinating each side of her body and using each arm and leg equally, there's no cause for concern.

assumption: There is a normal timeframe for babies to start crawling.
evidence: Developmental milestones are based on averages, and each child develops on their own unique timeline. While many babies begin crawling around 8 months of age on average, this skill can develop anywhere from 7 months to 11 months of age. If your 8-month-old is not crawling, they might just be taking a little longer to get the hang of it.

assumption: If a baby doesn't crawl at the appropriate time, it could indicate a problem.
evidence: Not all babies crawl. Some go straight to walking and skip the crawling stage completely. But if your baby is 12 months or older and isn't crawling, or if you're concerned about any areas of your baby's development, you might ask your doctor

assumption: There is an average age at which babies start crawling.
evidence: Babies usually start crawling when they are between 7 and 12 months old.

assumption: There is a point at which it is considered abnormal if a baby has not started crawling.
evidence: Not all babies crawl. Some go straight to walking and skip the crawling stage completely. But if your baby is 12 months or older and isn't crawling, or if you're concerned about any areas of your baby's development, you might ask your doctor

assumption: There may be reasons why a baby does not crawl at the expected time.
evidence: A few children never crawl. Instead, they use alternative methods, such as scooting on their bottoms or slithering on their stomachs. As long as your baby is coordinating each side of her body and using each arm and leg equally, there's no cause for concern.

assumption: A call to the pediatrician may be necessary if a baby has not started crawling.
evidence: If your baby regularly only uses one side of their body to propel themselves or push up, or doesn't show any signs of self-initiated movements, discuss it with your pediatrician. They can assess your baby's developmental path and recommend a physical or occupational therapist if needed.

question: Folic acid til which month?
assumption: It is necessary to take folic acid before and during pregnancy.
evidence: Do not worry if you have not taken folic acid before conceiving or in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy. It is still likely that your baby will develop normally. Routine ultrasound checks at around 12 and 20 weeks will detect if there are any concerns.

assumption: There are reasons to take folic acid when attempting pregnancy.
evidence: A baby's neural tube starts developing in the first 4 weeks of pregnancy (before your first missed period). So it's best to start taking folic acid as soon as you start trying to get pregnant.

assumption: There can be consequences if a person desiring pregnancy doesn't take folic acid.
evidence: In the UK and Ireland in the 1980s, before women were advised to take folic acid supplements, about 1 in 200 pregnancies resulted in a baby with a neural tube defect.

assumption: Taking too much folic acid or taking it for too long can cause harm.
evidence: Folic acid is generally very safe. Taking too much is unlikely to cause any harm.

assumption: There is a time during pregnancy when folic acid should be stopped.
evidence: Current US recommendations include (a) for women at high risk of having a child with a NTD (such as those with a personal or family history of NTD, a prior child with a NTD, or those on anticonvulsant medications), dietary supplementation with 5 mg folic acid daily prior to conception; and (b) for all other reproductive-aged women, .4 to 1 mg folic acid daily for at least 2 to 3 months prior to conception, throughout pregnancy, and during the postpartum period.

question: What are the 6week old infant milestones?
assumption: There are expected milestones for a 6-week-old infant.
evidence: Here are things babies usually do by this age: make sounds other than crying, react to loud noises, holds head up when on belly, moves both arms and legs, opens hands, calms down when spoken to/picked up, looks in your face, smiles when you talk, watches when you move, looks at a toy for several seconds.

assumption: There are variations of normal for infant milestones.
evidence: Doctors use certain milestones to tell if a baby is developing as expected. There's a wide range of what's considered normal, so some babies gain skills earlier or later than others. Babies who were born prematurely may reach milestones later. Always talk with your doctor about your baby's progress.

assumption: Pediatricians may check for the expected milestones.
evidence: Your doctor and/or nurse will probably: check babies weight, length, and head circumference, ask questions, listen to concerns and offer advice.

assumption: There may be a concern if the baby has not reached the expected milestones.
evidence: Talk to your doctor if your baby is not meeting one or more milestones, or you notice that your baby had skills but has lost them.

assumption: Failure to reach milestones may not always result in problems for children or adults later in life.
evidence: There's a wide range of what's considered normal, so some babies gain skills earlier or later than others.

question: How do I know if my baby is right handed?
assumption: Handedness is something that can be determined in babies.
evidence: Very young children often use both hands equally. Hand preference in the early years seems to rely on which hand is closer to the desired object; for example, a toddler may reach for a toy on their left side with their left hand because of convenience, regardless of future hand preference.

assumption: There is a likelihood of a baby being left or right handed (or ambidextrous).
evidence: lthough the percentage varies worldwide, in Western countries, 85 to 90 percent of people are right-handed and 10 to 15 percent of people are left-handed. Mixed-handedness (preferring different hands for different tasks) and ambidextrousness (the ability to perform tasks equally well with either hand) are uncommon.

assumption: There are usual ways to tell if a baby is right or left handed.
evidence: We have found that hand preferences are developing in a cascading fashion with preferences for earlier developing manual skills (e.g., reaching, grasping/acquisition) concatenating into preferences for later developing skills (e.g., unimanual and bimanual manipulation, artifact construction, and tool-use).

assumption: Handedness becomes apparent at a certain age.
evidence: Most children have a preference for using one hand or the other by the age of about 18 months, and are definitely right or left-handed by about the age of three.

assumption: There may be benefits to being right or left handed.
evidence: Since 90 per cent of the population is right-handed, left-handed people do experience some practical problems, including: Western writing runs left to right (smudging), they tend to learn to write back to front, implements such as scissors and circular saws are designed for the right hand,

assumption: It may be important to know early which hand my child is dominant in.
evidence: If your child is naturally left-handed, don't try to force them into using their right hand. While we know very little about what influences hand preference, we do know that handedness reflects the wiring of the individual brain.

question: What cough medicine is appropriate for breastfeeding mothers?
assumption: There are major types of cough medicine.
evidence: There are lots of different cold and cough medicines, and they do different things: nasal decongestants, cough suppressants, expectorants (loosens mucus in lungs to cough up), antihistamines, adn pain relievers.

assumption: Some cough medicines can be secreted in breast milk.
evidence: When it comes to cold medications, most only enter your breastmilk in small amounts, and they won't affect your baby. But others may have side effects for your baby or affect your milk supply. We'll talk about these next.

assumption: There may be potential harm to a breast feeding baby if the mother takes certain cough medicines.
evidence: Some medicines can cause your baby to have diarrhoea or make them sleepy or irritable. Other medicines can change your breast milk supply.

assumption: It may be necessary to feed formula for a while if taking cough medicine.
evidence: The good news is that there are several over-the-counter (OTC) cold medications you can take while breastfeeding without putting your baby at risk.

question: When should I start tummy time ?
assumption: Tummy time is necessary and important for babies.
evidence: Babies need tummy time!1 Although it does not directly reduce the risk of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), tummy time is an important way to help baby grow and develop.

assumption: There are benefits to doing tummy time.
evidence: It helps: strengthen baby's neck, shoulder, and arm muscles. Improve baby's ability to move and control their muscles. Helps prevent flat spots on baby's head

assumption: The duration of tummy time should increase gradually.
evidence: Most babies can start tummy time sessions a day or two after they are born. Babies benefit from having two or three short (3- to 5-minute) tummy time sessions each day. As your baby gets older, you can have longer, more regular sessions throughout the day. Pediatricians recommend that by about 2 months of age, babies be getting 15 to 30 minutes of total tummy time daily.

assumption: There may be negative consequences if tummy time isn't started.
evidence_source: Are You Doing Tummy Time Correctly With Your Baby?connecticutchildrens.orghttps://www.connecticutchildrens.org › physical-therapy
evidence: Babies that don't get enough tummy time might take longer to develop some motor skills. For example, they might be slower to develop core strength, coordination and balance, and take longer to build related skills like reaching and crawling.

question: How many calories do I need during pregnancy?
assumption: Calorie needs change during pregnancy.
evidence: During the second and third trimester, the development of the fetus and pregnancy-associated changes in the mother occur, i.e., increased blood volume, cardiac output, increase energy requirements by ~390 kcal/d, with small variations between women of differing body sizes.

assumption: Calorie needs may change throughout pregnancy.
evidence: energy intake requirements during the first trimester are minimally different from requirements before pregnancy

assumption: There are potential harms associated with not getting enough calories during pregnancy.
evidence_source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (.gov)Jun 13, 2022Weight Gain During Pregnancy | Maternal and Infant Health
evidence: Gaining less than the recommended amount of weight in pregnancy is associated with delivering a baby who is too small. Some babies born too small may have difficulty starting breastfeeding, may be at increased risk for illness, and may experience developmental delays

assumption: There are potential harms associated with getting too many calories during pregnancy.
evidence_source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (.gov)Jun 13, 2022Weight Gain During Pregnancy | Maternal and Infant Health
evidence: Gaining more than the recommended amount of weight in pregnancy is associated with having a baby who is born too large, which can lead to delivery complications, cesarean delivery, and obesity during childhood. Gaining more than the recommended amount of weight can also increase the amount of weight you hold on to after pregnancy, which can lead to obesity.

question: Are swimming classes okay for my 6 month old?
assumption: Starting babies in swimming classes early is important.
evidence: Recent studies suggest that water survival skills training and swim lessons can help reduce drowning risk for children between ages 1-4. Classes that include both parents and their children also are a good way to introduce good water safety habits and start building swim readiness skills.

assumption: There is a best time to start a baby in swimming classes.
evidence: The AAP recommends swim lessons as a layer of protection against drowning that can begin for many children starting at age 1.

assumption: There are certain developmental milestones that a baby must have reached to start swimming classes.
evidence: there is currently no evidence that infant swim programs for babies under 1 year old lower their drowning risk. Infants this age may show reflex "swimming" movements but can't yet raise their heads out of the water well enough to breathe.

assumption: There may be harm that can occur if swimming classes are started too early.
evidence: These findings suggest that while experience in baby swimming programs promoted more adaptive behaviors on drop-offs leading into bodies of water, sloped entries may heighten drowning risks for young children with greater familiarity with water.

assumption: There are things to consider to ensure safe swimming lessons for a 6 month old.
evidence: Include "touch supervision." Whenever infants and toddlers are in or around water—even during swim lessons―an adult should be within arm's reach to provide "touch supervision." Parent participation should be encouraged, especially since it also helps families know what to practice in between classes. If you can't be in the water with your child, look for private classes that offer 1-on-1 instruction.

question: Which baby bottles are recommended by lactation consultants?
assumption: There are pros and cons to both bottle feeding and breastfeeding.
evidence: Here are other reasons women may choose to bottle feed: convenience (anyone can feed baby at any time), flexibilty (once bottles are made, mother can leave baby with other caregivers).

assumption: There are different types of baby bottles.
evidence: There are many bottle brands, nipple sizes and styles of bottles to choose from. Some bottles are designed to look like a human nipple. Other bottles are designed to decrease colic or reflux.

assumption: There is a way to determine which type of baby bottle is better than another.
evidence: When looking for a bottle and nipple for your baby, it's important to look for 2 things: nipple flow rate and shape. Some bottle systems come with nipples that are a faster flow and are for older babies and/or babies who feed vigorously and can handle a faster flow. Some are also designed for babies who are on thickened feedings.

assumption: It is important to pick the correct baby bottle to avoid feeding or other problems with my baby.
evidence: When looking for a bottle and nipple for your baby, it's important to look for 2 things: nipple flow rate and shape. Some bottle systems come with nipples that are a faster flow and are for older babies and/or babies who feed vigorously and can handle a faster flow. Some are also designed for babies who are on thickened feedings.

assumption: Lactation consultants are the experts on which baby bottles to use.
evidence: Lactation specialists can help women manage breast engorgement and comfortably decrease their milk supply. They can also answer questions and provide tips about bottle feeding, such as the best bottles or nipples to use for your baby's specific feeding needs.

question: How can I push the baby out of my vaginal canal?
assumption: There is a way to push a baby out of the vaginal canal.
evidence: A vaginal delivery is when a person gives birth through their vagina. Vaginal deliveries are the most common and most preferred method of delivery. This is because they are typically low-risk and carry the most benefits to the birthing person and baby.

assumption: It may be necessary to push a baby out of the vaginal canal.
evidence: The “old way” of assisting women during second-stage labor typically involves pushing immediately at 10 cm regardless of whether the woman has an urge to push;. the best approach based on current evidence is to encourage the woman to do whatever comes naturally; for example, bearing down and holding it as long as she can, rather than insisting that she hold her breath for 10 to 15 seconds to the count of 10

assumption: There may be negative side effects to pushing a baby out of the vaginal canal.
evidence: vaginal deliveries carry the least risk but can still come with complications: failure to progress, irregular fetal heart rate, hemmorrhage, vaginal tears, deep vein thrombosis, postpartum preeclampsia.

assumption: There may be negative side effects to not pushing a baby out of the vaginal canal.
evidence: Risks of a C-section include: infection, loss of blood, blood clot, injury to bowel or bladder, weakened uterine wall, fetal injury, more difficult recovery, more likely to have c-section in the future.

assumption: I don't want the baby to stay in my vaginal canal for too long.
evidence: Babies who stay in the birth canal too long may be at greater risk for developmental diseases including but not limited to cerebral palsy, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), autism, and more. Furthermore, both the child and the mother are at risk of physical injur

assumption: I'm not sure how to push the baby out.
evidence: In this stage of labor, you experience strong contractions and begin pushing. You may feel pressure or like you need to poop. Your healthcare provider may coach you through pushing, especially if you've had an epidural and can't feel contractions.

assumption: I'm very worried about the pain/discomfort I may experience in the final stages of labor/delivery.
evidence: is vaginal delivery painful? Yes, it can be painful. There are many options to help manage your pain during a vaginal delivery. Some people choose to get an epidural block. An epidural numbs your body from the waist down. Discuss your options for pain relief with your healthcare provider.

assumption: The baby could be harmed by being in the vaginal canal too
evidence: Babies who stay in the birth canal too long may be at greater risk for developmental diseases including but not limited to cerebral palsy, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), autism, and more. Furthermore, both the child and the mother are at risk of physical injur

question: When should my baby start holding her own bottle ?
assumption: Babies can safely hold a bottle at a certain age.
evidence: Between the ages of 6 and 8 months, most babies acquire the necessary fine motor skills to be able to hold objects such as cups and bottles with their hands and fingers.

assumption: There may be some potential dangers associated with a baby holding their own bottle.
evidence: Even if your baby can hold their own bottle, that doesn't mean that your baby should hold their own bottle. They could fall asleep with the bottle in their mouth, which can lead to tooth decay, ear infections, and even choking.

assumption: There may be a potential delay in future developmental milestones if the baby does not hold their own bottle.
evidence: There really is no need to teach your baby to hold their own bottle, since you can already start teaching them to drink from a cup around 6 months of age. This is around the same time that babies learn how to grasp objects with both hands. So instead of teaching your baby to hold their bottle, focus on teaching them to hold a cup and drink from a cup. At first you'll need to hold the cup for them, but they'll eventually learn to confidently hold and handle the cup.

question: How long will it take a baby to poop from breastfeeding?
assumption: Breastfeeding may impact a baby's bowel movements.
evidence: Exclusively breastfed infants produced more stools than exclusively formula fed infants during the first two months and more liquid stools during the first three.

assumption: There are normal expectations for a baby's bowel movements.
evidence: After the first week, poop from babies who have received only breast milk will be yellow and can look seedy. After the first week up to about 6 weeks, your baby might have 6 or more poops a day (24 hours). After about 6 weeks, your baby may have fewer poops each day.

question: How do you know if the baby has hair?
assumption: Babies start to grow hair at a certain point in their development.
evidence: Hair follicles start to form deep in your baby's skin by 14 weeks of pregnancy.

assumption: The amount and velocity of hair growth may vary from baby to baby.
evidence: By 22 weeks, hair is visible on your baby's head – and may grow like a weed or only slightly by the end of pregnancy. In the weeks after hair starts growing, cells that produce melanin get to work and begin to add color to the strands.

assumption: It may be possible to see hair on an ultrasound during pregnancy.
evidence: Unfortunately 3D/4D ultrasound technology cannot see any hair on the baby, however standard 2d (black and white) ultrasound can usually pick up strands of hair!

question: How old before my baby grows a tooth?
assumption: There is an average age at which babies get their first tooth.
evidence: There is a wide range of variability of when a first tooth may appear, but a first tooth usually appears around 6 months old.

assumption: There is such a thing as delayed tooth development.
evidence: An infant with delayed or absent tooth formation may have other symptoms and signs that indicate a specific medical condition.

assumption: There may be some ramifications of delayed tooth development.
evidence: An infant with delayed or absent tooth formation may have other symptoms and signs that indicate a specific medical condition. Medical tests are not often needed. Most of the time, delayed tooth formation is normal. Dental x-rays may be done.

assumption: There may be some treatments available if teeth don't come in when expected.
evidence: Sometimes, children or adults are missing teeth they never developed. Cosmetic or orthodontic dentistry can correct this problem.

assumption: Growing a tooth too early or too late may not be ideal.
evidence: The occurrence of natal and neonatal teeth is an uncommon anomaly. Early detection and treatment of these teeth are recommended because they may induce deformity or mutilation of tongue, dehydration, inadequate nutrients intake by the infant, and growth retardation, the pattern and time of eruption of teeth and its morphology.

assumption: There may be possible pain associated with breastfeeding if a baby grows its first tooth too soon.
evidence: A newly-emerged tooth is very sharp, in order to help it cut through the gum, so you may get a scratch from it during feeding. If your nipple is sore because of a bite or scratch, try using a different feeding position next time so that your baby's teeth don't touch the sore spot, and treat between feeds with pure lanolin or a hydrogel pad if necessary.

question: Which kind of food to avoid during breastfeeding?
assumption: There are foods or nutrients that can cross into breast milk.
evidence: Generally, women do not need to limit or avoid specific foods while breastfeeding. Mothers should be encouraged to eat a healthy and diverse diet. However, certain types of seafood should be consumed in a limited amount and some mothers may wish to restrict caffeine while breastfeeding.

assumption: Some of these foods or nutrients can cause harm to a baby during breastfeeding.
evidence: Although fish remains an excellent source of protein and contains essential vitamins and minerals for breastfeeding women, some care must be taken in deciding on the amount and types of seafood to consume. Most fish contain some amount of mercury, which accumulates in fish flesh and can pass from mother to infant through breast milk. This can have adverse effects on the brain and nervous system of the breastfed infant.

assumption: There are potential harms that can occur from certain foods eaten during breastfeeding.
evidence: Most fish contain some amount of mercury, which accumulates in fish flesh and can pass from mother to infant through breast milk. This can have adverse effects on the brain and nervous system of the breastfed infant.

assumption: There is a possibility that a baby can be harmed from eating certain foods just one time or occasionally.
evidence: Breastfeeding women (as well as pregnant women, women of childbearing age) should follow the US Food and Drug Administration's (FDA) and the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) advice about eating fish: eat a variety, check for fish advisories, try to avoid eating the "choices to avoid" fish.

assumption: I have to be cautious and avoid certain foods while breastfeeding.
evidence: certain types of seafood should be consumed in a limited amount and some mothers may wish to restrict caffeine while breastfeeding. If an infant appears to be more fussy or irritable after the mother consumes high amounts of caffeine, she should consider decreasing her intake. Preterm and younger newborn infants break down caffeine more slowly, so mothers of these infants might consider consuming even less caffeine.

question: What should I do about pregnancy fatigue?
assumption: Fatigue is a common experience during pregnancy.
evidence: Fatigue is one of the most common and persistent complaints of pregnant women.

assumption: There are potential causes of fatigue in pregnancy.
evidence: Hormone changes play a big role in making you feel tired, especially the hormone progesterone. This hormone rises sharply in the first trimester. In addition, as blood volume increases to supply the developing placenta and fetal circulation, your heart pumps faster and stronger.

assumption: There are signs that indicate excessive fatigue in pregnancy.
evidence: Occasionally, sleeplessness and fatigue – when accompanied by other symptoms – can be a sign of depression. If you have any of the other symptoms of depression, such as feeling hopeless and losing interest in the things you used to enjoy, speak to your doctor or midwife. There is treatment that can help.

assumption: There are strategies to minimize fatigue in pregnancy.
evidence: what can you do to feel better: good nutrition, stretching, deep breathing, brisk walks when available, take naps, drink enough fluids.

question: How do I treat a clogged milk duct?
assumption: There are signs that indicate a clogged milk duct.
evidence: One of the biggest signs of a blocked milk duct is a hard lump on your breast. It'll be painful or sore when you touch it. It may be red or large enough to be visible if you look at your breast in a mirror.

assumption: A clogged milk duct may not be dangerous.
evidence: Clogged milk ducts are common during breastfeeding and can cause discomfort, pain and infection. It's important to treat a plugged duct as soon as you feel it. Luckily, you can treat it at home most of the time.

assumption: There are treatments available for a clogged milk duct.
evidence: Some of the best ways to clear a clogged milk duct are easily remembered by the acronym B.A.I.T: Breast rest: Don't over massage or overfeed. Decrease production if you have an oversupply. Advil: 800 milligrams (mg) every eight hours for 48 hours.Ice: Apply for 10 minutes at a time while laying on your back. Repeat every 30 minutes. Tylenol: 1,000 mg every 8 eight hours for 48 hours.

assumption: It may be possible to treat a clogged milk duct without a doctor's visit.
evidence: Most people can unclog a milk duct at home within two days.

assumption: There may be a point at which a doctor's visit is necessary for a clogged milk duct.
evidence: Call your obstetrician right away if you notice signs of mastitis since it needs to be treated with antibiotics.

question: How many  vaccines should my baby get ?
assumption: Vaccines are recommended for babies on a specific schedule.
evidence: 2023 Recommended Immunizations for Children from Birth Through 6 Years Old

assumption: There are benefits and risks associated with vaccines in babies.
evidence: Part of taking care of kids is setting them up for a healthy future. Vaccines play a big part in health. Vaccines for illnesses such as diphtheria, rotavirus, polio, tetanus, whooping cough, also called pertussis, and others are given in the first year of life. If these diseases seem uncommon it's because vaccines are doing their job. Some examples are a low-grade fever, headache, fussiness or soreness at the injection site.

assumption: There is a potential harm that can come from having too few or too many vaccines.
evidence: It's not a good idea to skip some vaccines. That leaves your child without protection. It allows a child to spread disease to others. For some children, such as kids being treated for cancer, their main protection from disease is the immunity of the people around them.

assumption: Vaccines are a type of medical intervention.
evidence: Vaccines for children are timed carefully. Vaccines are given when protection inherited from the mother fades and the child's immune system is ready, but before kids come in contact with the germs that cause real infections.

question: What is a high temp for a baby?
assumption: Babies have a normal temperature range that is different from older children or adults.
evidence: Normal body temperature varies with age, general health, activity level, and time of day. Infants tend to have higher temperatures than older children

assumption: There is a temperature at which a mild fever in a baby may be a cause for concern.
evidence: Infants younger than 3 months: If an infant younger than 3 months has a rectal temperature of 100.4°F (38°C) or higher, call your doctor or go to the emergency department right away.

assumption: There is a temperature at which it is necessary to call a pediatrician.
evidence: The temperature that should trigger a call to the doctor depends on a child's age, the illness, and whether they have other symptoms. in general call a doctor if your child is young than 3 months w/ rectal temp of 100.4 or higher, 3 months + with a tem higher than 102.2

assumption: There is a temperature that is considered dangerously high for a baby, and there may be potential ramifications associated with it.
evidence: call your doctor right away if your child:  Has a fever of over 104 degrees F (or 40 degrees C)/

question: Why is my babies nose stuffy every morning?
assumption: There are potential causes for a stuffy nose in a baby.
evidence: Baby snuffles are usually due to the normal mucus that may collect in a baby's nose. Snuffles are not caused by colds or infections - although an infection can make things worse. Snuffles can be common in newborns. Babies have to breathe through their nose and they cannot make themselves sneeze or blow their nose to clear it.

assumption: There may be specific reasons why a baby would have a stuffy nose in the morning.
evidence: It is common for babies aged under 6 months to have a blocked nose (commonly called 'snuffles'). It is usually due to normal mucus that collects in the nose, which is difficult for the baby to clear. No treatment is required if the baby is otherwise well and feeding well.

assumption: A stuffy nose in the morning may not be something to worry about.
evidence: Most babies with snuffles come to no harm and feed well. In some cases babies with snuffles feed more slowly and with some difficulty. If you are concerned that feeding is a problem, see your health visitor or doctor.

assumption: There are treatments available for a stuffy nose in a baby.
evidence: Nasal aspirators are devices which allow you to suck the mucus from your baby's nose. They come in various shapes and sizes. Some are bulb syringes, some come with a tube so you can suck at the other end and some are electrically powered

question: When do babies start speaking?
assumption: There is a normal age range for babies to say their first words.
evidence: • Says 1 or 2 words, like hi, dog, dada, mama, or uh-oh. This will happen around their first birthday, but sounds may not be clear.

assumption: There may be normal reasons for a baby's speech to be delayed.
evidence: Many kids with speech delays have oral–motor problems. These happen when there's a problem in the areas of the brain responsible for speech. This makes it hard to coordinate the lips, tongue, and jaw to make speech sounds. These kids also might have other oral-motor problems, such as feeding problems.

assumption: There is a potential concern if a baby hasn't started speaking by a certain age.
evidence: contact your child's doctor if they do not: try to say 1-2 words other than mama or dada by 15 months, look at a familiar object when you name it by 15 months, say 3 or more words by 18 months, follow 1-step directions without gestures by 18 months, point to two things by 2, put 2 words together by 2.

assumption: There are common reasons for speech delay in babies.
evidence: A speech delay might be due to: an oral impairment, like problems with the tongue or palate. A short frenulum which can limit tongue movement. hearing problems

assumption: It could be a sign of a serious developmental delay if a child doesn't start speaking on time.
evidence: Some parents worry that a toddler who is not speaking may have autism. Doctors look for signs of autism at every checkup and do screening tests for autism at 18 months and 2 years.

question: How many times a week can I shower my baby?
assumption: Showering a baby may not be necessary.
evidence: Lots of bathing can lead to dry, irritated skin. But also, the skin has natural protective oils, and natural bacteria, that help to keep us healthy and safe — and that can get washed away with daily bathing. If your baby or preteen looks pretty clean, isn't stinky, isn't covered in bug spray, and hasn't been in a pool or other body of water, it's fine to skip the bath or shower.

assumption: There may be some dangers associated with showering a baby at a too early gestational age.
evidence: Here are some reasons why it is now recommended to delay baby's first bath: body temp and blood sugar (can lead to hypothermia and/or hypoglycemia). bonding and breastfeeding, dry skin (by cleaning off the vernix too early).

assumption: There are alternatives to showering a baby.
evidence: A sponge bath is like a regular bath, except you don't put your baby in the water.

question: How good can my baby see at 4 months?
assumption: Babies may not see clearly at birth.
evidence: at birth, your baby: sees in black and white, is not very light-senstive.

assumption: There is an age at which most babies start seeing clearly.
evidence: One week after birth, your baby will start to slowly develop color vision. They can also see about 8 10 10 inches away. At 6 weeks of age, a baby can see about 12 inches away.

assumption: There are signs that a baby may not be seeing clearly.
evidence: call your baby's doctor if: their eyes do not work together, they are not tracking iems, they tilt their head to one side to view objets, are very sensitive to light, they close one eye most of the time.

question: Can my baby see light at 18 weeks pregnant?
assumption: Light is able to penetrate through the stomach and into the uterus.
evidence: If you shine a flashlight at your tummy, you may feel your baby respond with a burst of flutters and wiggles.

assumption: There is a gestational age at which the eyes are developed enough to see.
evidence: At 31 weeks, the pupils are able to constrict and expand, allowing the eyes to let in more or less light. Because your baby has more rods than cones at this point, they may be able to detect the dim outlines of shapes, but not their colors. Also at 31 weeks, your baby can blink in response to bright light.

assumption: There have been studies done to determine when babies can see and if they can see light in utero.
evidence: We have developed a light source for delivering visual stimuli to be seen by the fetal eye, using laser dot diodes emitting at 650 nm. The 2D component of 94 fetal ultrasound scans (mean gestational age 240 days), where the light stimulus was presented, was coded to determine whether the eyes moved in response to the stimuli independent of any head movement.

assumption: My baby may be harmed/disturbed by too much exposure to light at 18 weeks.
evidence: The results showed that being exposed to UV radiation during the first 3 months of pregnancy is associated with improved fetal growth and causes high blood pressure during pregnancy.

assumption: Babies can see light while they are in utero.
evidence: It has been shown that from 31 weeks gestational age the fetal sensory system is capable of directed vision if enough light is available.

question: What is considered as normal blood pressure?
assumption: High blood pressure can be very serious in pregnancy.
evidence_source: Mayo Clinichttps://www.mayoclinic.org › pregnancy › art-20046098High blood pressure and pregnancy: Know the facts
evidence: High blood pressure during pregnancy poses the following risks: Less blood flow to the placenta. If the placenta doesn't get enough blood, the fetus might receive less oxygen and fewer nutrients. This can lead to slow growth (intrauterine growth restriction), low birth weight or premature birth.

assumption: There is a normal range of blood pressure for adults.
evidence_source: March of Dimeshttps://www.marchofdimes.org › find-support › topicsHigh blood pressure during pregnancy | March of Dimes
evidence: Normal. Your blood pressure is less than 120/80.

assumption: Normal blood pressure may change during pregnancy.
evidence: Some women have high blood pressure before they get pregnant. Others develop it for the first time during pregnancy.

assumption: There may be different levels at which blood pressure is considered too high or too low during pregnancy.
evidence: Normal: Less than 120/80 mm Hg. Elevated: Systolic between 120 and 129 mm Hg and diastolic less than 80 mm Hg

assumption: There is a clinical significance to having elevated or low blood pressure.
evidence: During pregnancy, severe or uncontrolled high blood pressure can cause problems for you and your fetus. A serious high blood pressure disorder called preeclampsia can also happen during pregnancy or soon after childbirth.

question: How long does the baby have sensitive skin?
assumption: Babies may have more sensitive skin than older children and adults.
evidence: In infants, the stratum corneum is thinner, water handling is different, and natural moisturizing factor and skin lipid production are reduced compared with adults. Because of these developmental differences, the skin in children may be more sensitive to irritation and inflammation.

assumption: There is a certain age at which babies no longer have sensitive skin.
evidence: Children had a more permeable skin barrier that matured to adult values by approximately 5 years of age.

assumption: There are precautions that need to be taken due to the sensitivity of babies' skin.
evidence: keep your baby clean, change dirty diapers as soon as possible (to avoid rashes), trim your baby's nails (to avoid scratches), wash baby blanket, sheets, and clothing in fragrance-free detergents before use, protect baby from the sun (to avoid sunburn).

assumption: Exposure to different substances can cause skin irritation in babies.
evidence: Skin cleansing and emollient use are two simple strategies that can help keep skin healthy. Proper skin cleansing helps keep infant skin free of unwanted irritants, including saliva, nasal secretions, urine, feces, fecal enzymes, dirt, and microbial pathogens. Exposure to such factors for long periods, especially in the diaper region, can lead to discomfort, irritation, infection, and skin barrier breakdown. In addition to using cleansers during bathing, emollient use during or after bathing also may have benefits. Emollients decrease transepidermal water loss, improve skin condition.

question: What senses are babies experiencing at 4 months?
assumption: Babies have different senses.
evidence: Babies are born with all 5 senses—sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch. Some of the senses are not fully developed.

assumption: Babies may not exhibit all senses at birth.
evidence: Newborns can detect light and dark but can't see all colors. Hearing is fully developed in newborns. Babies with normal hearing should startle in response to loud sounds.Studies have found that newborns have a strong sense of smell. Babies prefer sweet tastes over sour or bitter tastes. Babies also show a strong preference for human milk and breastfeeding. Babies are comforted by touch.

assumption: Babies may become more sensitive to light, sound, etc as they get older.
evidence: vision is the most poorly developed sense at birth. Newborns typically cannot see further than 8 to 16 inches away from their faces, have difficulty keeping a moving object within their gaze, and can detect contrast more than color differences.

assumption: There is a development of senses as the baby ages and grows.
evidence: However, by 2 or 3 months, they will seek more detail when exploring an object visually and begin showing preferences for unusual images over familiar ones and for patterns over solids and faces over patterns and three-dimensional objects over flat images.

question: When should I stop breast feeding?
assumption: There may be an ideal time to stop breastfeeding.
evidence: It is up to you and your baby to decide when the time is right to stop breastfeeding.

assumption: There are maternal and newborn factors that should be considered when determining when to stop breastfeeding.
evidence: Approximately 60% of mothers who stopped breastfeeding did so earlier than desired. Early termination was positively associated with mothers' concerns regarding: (1) difficulties with lactation; (2) infant nutrition and weight; (3) illness or need to take medicine; and (4) the effort associated with pumping milk.

assumption: There may be potential harms to stopping breastfeeding too soon or too late.
evidence: There is ample evidence that babies who are breastfed for the first 6 months of life do not experience as many (or as severe) episodes of common childhood illnesses. These include gastroenteritis, respiratory illnesses and middle ear infections.

assumption: Breastfeeding for too long could cause physical or psychological problems for my child.
evidence: Some parents and babies enjoy breastfeeding so much they are in no hurry to stop. It is not unusual for children up to 4 years of age to continue to be breastfed.

assumption: Breastfeeding may be difficult or inconvenient and I'd like to know the earliest point when I can stop.
evidence: The most common reasons cited were inconvenience or fatigue associated with breastfeeding (22.6%) and concerns about milk supply (21.6%). Return to work or school was associated with length of time that infants were breastfed: 20% of women who stopped after six weeks citing this as the reason.

question: When should I transition from formula to baby food?
assumption: There may not be a uniform best time to transition from formula to baby food.
evidence: A healthy baby should drink breast milk or formula until they are 1 year old. Formulas are fortified with vitamins and iron, which they need,” says pediatrician Radhai Prabhakaran, MD. “Generally, babies should have at least 24 ounces per day between the ages of 9 months to 1 year. But once your baby starts eating a full diet of nutritious solid foods, make the switch to cow's milk, which offers protein and vitamin D.”

assumption: There are factors that should be taken into consideration when determining the timing of the transition.
evidence: Whether babies are ready to hop aboard the milk express depends on their taste for table food. “Some babies settle into a mostly solid food diet early (between 9 and 12 months) because they like it, and it agrees with them. If they're eating a nutritionally balanced diet, then it's OK to wean your baby off formula earlier than 1 year old.”

assumption: There is an absolute earliest safe age to transition to baby food from formula.
evidence: Some babies settle into a mostly solid food diet early (between 9 and 12 months) because they like it, and it agrees with them. If they're eating a nutritionally balanced diet, then it's OK to wean your baby off formula earlier than 1 year old.”

assumption: Harm may come to my baby if he/she stays on formula too long.
evidence: Before their first birthday, babies still need the nutrients in breast milk or formula. But after that, they're ready to switch to cow's milk. Most kids under age 2 should drink whole milk.

assumption: Formula may not provide the needed nutrients and calories as my baby gets older and it's important for me not to wait too long to transition.
evidence: once your baby starts eating a full diet of nutritious solid foods, make the switch to cow's milk, which offers protein and vitamin D.”

question: How often do I have to feed the baby?
assumption: Babies can be fed on a schedule or on demand.
evidence: In the past, Western “baby experts” often instructed parents to feed their babies at regularly-spaced intervals of 3- or 4-hours. Today, official medical recommendations have shifted in favor of letting babies decide.

assumption: There may be a best schedule to start with for feeding babies.
evidence: If newborn babies aren't fed frequently enough, they are at higher risk for dehydration and underfeeding. So the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) advises parents to feed infants at least once every 2-3 hours — whenever babies show signs of hunger (AAP 2015).

assumption: There may not be a standard schedule for all babies.
evidence: A feeding schedule is not necessary — you and your baby will get into a routine. Babies know (and will let their parents know) when they're hungry and when they've had enough. Watch for signs that your baby is full (slowing down, spitting out the bottle or unlatching from breast, closing the mouth, turning away from the breast or bottle) and stop the feeding when these signs appear.

assumption: The feeding schedule may need to change as the baby grows.
evidence: As babies grow, they begin to eat more at each feeding and can go longer between feedings. There may be other times when your infant seems hungrier than usual. Continue to nurse or feed on demand. Nursing mothers need not worry — breastfeeding stimulates milk production, and your supply of breast milk will adjust to your baby's demand for it.

question: What games can I play with my baby?
assumption: Playing games with my baby has benefits.
evidence: Learning is best fueled by tapping into a child's natural urge to play, rather than just outside factors like test scores. As they actively engage with and joyfully discover their world, children gain 21st century skills that increasingly call for teamwork and innovation. The AAP encourages parents to use play to help meet their child's health and developmental milestones, beginning from birth.

assumption: There are different games that are appropriate at different developmental ages.
evidence: Birth to 6 months: imitate baby's coos and babbles, show interesting objects. 7 to 12 months: use a mirror, give baby opportunities to learn that their actions have affects, play peek-a-boo. 1-3 years old: let child play with blocks, wooden spoons, etc., give child opportunities to play w peers, make believe play, sing songs.

assumption: There are examples of age-appropriate games that I can play with my baby.
evidence: Birth to 6 months: imitate baby's coos and babbles, show interesting objects. 7 to 12 months: use a mirror, give baby opportunities to learn that their actions have affects, play peek-a-boo. 1-3 years old: let child play with blocks, wooden spoons, etc., give child opportunities to play w peers, make believe play, sing songs.

question: Is better that my baby uses a pacifier or fingers?
assumption: Babies have a natural need to suck on objects.
evidence: Most babies have a strong sucking reflex. Some babies even suck their thumbs or fingers before they're born. Beyond helping with nutrition, sucking often has a soothing effect

assumption: There may be downsides to babies sucking on a finger or pacifier.
evidence: pitfalls of pacifiers: your baby might become dependent, might increase risk of middle ear infections, prolonged use might lead to dental problems, might disrupt breast-feeding.

assumption: There may be a reason that one choice is better than the other.
evidence: Many parents of a thumb-sucking infant question whether they should substitute a pacifier for the thumb. So far, research does not show that one is preferable over the other. Also, although parents can encourage a child to suck a pacifier rather than a thumb, they can't control which the child will prefer. The advantages of using a pacifier include being able to control when your child is allowed to use it and being able to take the pacifier away when it is no longer appropriate. An advantage of thumb-sucking is that it may not interfere with breastfeeding.

assumption: There may be an ideal time to start or stop the use of a pacifier or finger.
evidence: children usually stop on their own between the ages of 3 to 5. But if thumb-sucking is a habit past age 4, the child may develop dental problems. Also, it may be more difficult for a child to stop thumb-sucking than using a pacifier.

assumption: There may be some health benefits to using a pacifier or sucking on fingers.
evidence: A pacifier might help reduce the risk of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Sucking on a pacifier at nap time and bedtime might reduce the risk of SIDS.

question: What is the best way to get my child to read?
assumption: Failure to read could potentially have long-term consequences for a child.
evidence: Evidence shows that reading problems in childhood can be associated with negative outcomes in adulthood, including lower income, poorer self-esteem and higher rates of psychiatric problems.

assumption: There is a way to get a child to read that is considered the best.
evidence: esearch has shown that reading is not a natural process(1), and it's not a guessing game. Written language is a code. Certain combinations of letters predictably represent certain sounds. And for the last few decades, the research has been clear: Teaching young kids how to crack the code—teaching systematic phonics—is the most reliable way to make sure that they learn how to read words.

assumption: Children typically start to read at a certain age.
evidence: Early readers benefit from systematic phonics instruction. Among students in grades K-1, phonics instruction led to improvements in decoding ability and reading comprehension across the board, according to the National Reading Panel(

assumption: It may not be necessary for every child to read at the same time.
evidence: Keep in mind that kids develop at different paces and spend varying amounts of time at each stage. If you have concerns, talk to your child's doctor, teacher, or the reading specialist at school. Getting help early is key for helping kids who struggle to read.

assumption: Children may show an interest in certain topics that they may want to read about.
evidence: Children who read for pleasure are likely to do significantly better in school than their peers who rarely read. Sullivan and Brown (2013) demonstrate that pleasure reading is linked to increased cognitive progress over time. They recommend that educators and policy makers “support and encourage children's reading in their leisure time.”

question: Why doesn't my two year old communicate?
assumption: All babies should be communicating by two years old.
evidence: Every child grows and develops at their own pace. But toddler speech development tends to follow a fairly set path. For example, by age 2, most children can: use two-word phrases, ask one or two word questions, follow simple commands, speak 50-100 words, be understood at least half the time by adults who don't know them.

assumption: There are different forms of communication.
evidence: Infants and toddlers are able and ready communicators. They communicate through gestures, sounds, facial expressions, movements, and language.

assumption: There are signs that indicate a lack of communication in a two year old.
evidence: If an infant or toddler does not respond to you while communicating or react to loud noises, these may be signs that he or she is having trouble hearing or has a developmental delay. Infants and toddlers that do not show an interest in expressive language will also need extra support in understanding their strengths and needs.

assumption: There are statistically major forms of communication used by the average two year old.
evidence: By 24 months, children should point to things or pictures when named, says sentences with at least two words together, points to at least two body parts when asked, uses more gestures like blowing a kiss or nodding, repeats words overheard in conversation.

assumption: There is a range of normal in terms of the use of different forms of communication by age.
evidence: Keep in mind that individual differences exist when it comes to the specific age at which infants and toddlers meet these milestones and that each infant and toddler is unique.

question: How do I know if my baby is allergic to something?
assumption: There is a need to be able to recognize allergies quickly in order to eliminate the cause and prevent harm to the baby.
evidence: Allergic reactions can be triggered by foods, medicines, pets, insect stings, pollen, and other things. Most allergic reactions aren't serious. But severe reactions can be life-threatening and need medical care right away.

assumption: Allergies are common in babies.
evidence: Food allergies affect between 2 to 5 per cent of all children, in general, and up to 10 per cent of infants. Some of the most common allergenic foods are peanuts, eggs, milk and wheat.

assumption: There are different types and symptoms of allergies.
evidence: Signs of mild allergic reaction: itchy and swollen skin, change in skin tone, stuffy nose, sneezing, itchy eyes, hives. Signs of severe reaction: swelling of mouth or tongue, trouble swallowing, wheezing or trouble breathing, nausea/vomiting/diarrhea, dizziness or fainting.

assumption: Most allergies develop at a certain age.
evidence: “Allergic rhinitis can be caused by either an indoor or outdoor allergen,” Dr. Wessell says. “With outdoor allergens, you have to live through the season a few times to become sensitized. We tend to see outdoor triggered seasonal allergy symptoms in children after age 3, classically ages 5 to 6. Indoor allergen triggered symptoms can be seen earlier, as early as 1 year of age – because of things they're exposed to in the home on a regular basis, such as dust mites and pets.”

assumption: There are other conditions that can mimic allergies.
evidence: MCAS is a condition in which the patient experiences repeated episodes of the symptoms of anaphylaxis – allergic symptoms such as hives, swelling, low blood pressure, difficulty breathing and severe diarrhea The episodes are called “idiopathic” which means that the mechanism is unknown - that is, not caused by allergic antibody or secondary to other known conditions that activate normal mast cells.

assumption: Babies can be allergy tested at a certain age.
evidence: Percutaneous skin testing is rarely conducted on infants younger than 6 months old; otherwise there is no age limit. Intradermal testing, which is more sensitive, is used if the allergist strongly suspects a venom or penicillin allergy that was not detected by a percutaneous test.

question: What are normal kick counts?
assumption: Kick counts can help determine if a baby is healthy and appropriately active.
evidence: Counting fetal kicks (or movements) during pregnancy can be a valuable tool for monitoring the fetus's health. Kick counting involves counting the number of times you feel the fetus move in a specific time period. A change in the typical pattern could indicate the fetus is stressed.

assumption: There is a way to do kick counts.
evidence: Ten movements (kicks, flutters or rolls) in one hour is considered typical fetal movement. Don't panic if you don't feel 10 movements in an hour. Feeling fewer than 10 kicks doesn't mean something is wrong. It may also take a little longer than one hour to feel 10 movements. This is usually OK and not a cause for worry.

assumption: Kick counts are useful for something.
evidence: Kick counting can help you be more aware of fetal movements. If you know what's normal for the fetus, then you can more easily determine when something feels wrong. Changes in fetal movement may be an early sign of distress or can indicate a problem with the pregnancy. Once you know the fetus's activity level, you can alert your healthcare provider if changes occur.

assumption: There is a frequency of kick counts that is reassuring at different gestational ages.
evidence: Kicks from inside your uterus feel soft and may be hard to distinguish (especially the first movements). The fetus is small, and its movements aren't strong.
